IHWG Analyses Documentation for programs and methodology used for analyses of the IHWG population data.
Thomson Lab
University of California, Berkeley Department of Integrative Biology
Version 0.1 Last modified: $Date$ by $Author$
Introduction
One of the goals of the IHWG is to analyze data generated by the Anthropology component in the light of population genetics theory. In this document we offer a detailed outline of the methods used, their theoretical justification, the means by which they are implemented. We also provide a list of future developments and the status of the project.
Population background data
Information contained in the in the input file will be reported as part of the output, in order to aid interpretation of analyses.
The following items will be reported for each population which is analyzed. Note that this information concerns the population as a whole; individual loci for that population may have different values with respect to other fields (e.g. sample size).
lab code
typing method
ethnicity
origin (?)
collection site
latitude
longitude
Locus information and population genetics summary statistics
For each locus, for a given population sample, report:
The sample size (in number of alleles)
The number of distinct alleles in the sample (k)
The number of counts for each allele in the sample
The gene diversity of the sample
Future work: include information about ambiguity of allelic assignments. For example, report how many allele calls are ambiguous and maximum and minimum numbers of alleles (which will depend on how the ambiguity is resolved). Report standard error of the estimate of gene diversity (use resampling scheme for this?).
Analyses
Test for Hardy-Weinberg proportions
Method
Chi-square test of contingency table.
Input data
single locus genotypes
Methodological outline
Compute observed and expected numbers of individuals per genotypic category and test the null hypothesis of HWE assuming that deviations between observed and expected counts are chi-square distributed. Cells for which the expected counts are lower than 5 are pooled into a single class.
Output
The number of genotypes in the lumped category. The number of degrees of freedom for the overall test. The results are displayed in a diagonal matrix, where each cell represents a genotype. Cells along the diagonal are homozygotes.
The test results are reported at three levels;
each cell's contribution to the overall chi-square is reported;
the p-value for each cell's deviation from HWE is computed (? is this a 1 d.f. test?);
the overall deviation of all the cells from HWE is reported, in the form of an overall chi-square value.
Current status
debugging code and verifying specifications, in particular definition of the number of degrees of freedom for pooled data.
Future work
Implementation of exact test for contingency table, using the MCMC algorithm. Implementation of individual genotype tests for deviation from HWE using the test statistic described in John Chen's dissertation. Estimation of standard error around p-values? This can be done if resampling schemes are used.
Test of neutrality.
Method
Ewens-Watterson homozygosity test of neutrality
Input data
single locus genotypes; only the allele count information is used for this test.
Analysis
Estimate sample homozygosity. Use tables of neutral simulations to obtain expected F under neutrality, and fraction of simulation results with F_exp that exceeds F_obs, thus providing a p-value for the null hypothesis of neutrality. In the cases where there is no simulated 2n value that matches that of the sample use the next higher 2n, which will be conservative with respect the rejection of neutrality (explain in more detail).
Output
F_obs, F_exp, p-value
Current status
Complete, requires formatting.
Future work
Implement exact version of the test, which examines the distribution of homozygosity over all possible configurations of alleles, following Monty Slatkin's program. Also consider implementing the version of a test of neutrality that uses the probability of the configuration under neutrality (using the Ewens sampling formula).
Estimation of haplotype frequencies from multilocus genotypic data.
Method
Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm.
Input data
Multilocus genotype data.
Methodological outline
Using the EM algorithm, find the maximum likelihood estimate of haplotype frequencies.
Output
Estimated frequency of all haplotypes that are estimated to occur with a frequency above an arbitrarily set (low) threshold.
Current status
Code written in C, requires testing and integration with the remainder of the programs.
Future work
Provide guidelines for EM parameters (number of starting conditions used) that are required to obtain reliable estimates. Estimate and report standard errors of haplotype frequency estimates; this may be done using a resampling method.
Estimation of linkage disequilibrium values and p-values for a test of the null hypothesis that the data is in linkage equilibrium.
Method
Use inferred haplotypes to estimate LD values;
use likelihood ratio to test the null hypothesis that the data is in HW equilibrium.
Input data
Multilocus genotype data, from which haplotypes are inferred; these are then used to estimate haplotypes from which LD measures are estimated.
Multilocus genotypes are used to perform a likelihood ratio test of the null hypothesis of linkage equilibrium.
Methodological outline
For each pair of loci report tables with cells containing the values for (a) the observed and (b) the expected (under HWE) number of counts. Each cell refers to a specific two locus haplotype.
Chi-square values for each two locus haplotype.
LD value for all pairs of alleles.
LD value (normalized) for all pairs of alleles.
Disequilibrium summary measures (Wn, Q, D') which provide an overall measure of the degree of deviation from linkage equilibrium for the pair of loci.
Output
Not yet defined
Future work
Implementation of likelihood ratio test of linkage equilibrium. Testing of programme, addition of outputs for p-values for the null hypothesis of linkage equilibrium, for both the individual and overall measures of LD. Consider feasibility of developing exact test for testing of linkage equilibrium using MCMC approach (as heuristic for Fisher's exact test).

Data interchange
Data format
The data must come to us as plain ASCII text files.
The first two lines consist of fields related to population information we would like to have but will depend on the individual labs. e.g.:
Lab_name Typing_method Ethnic_group Continent Collection_site Latitude Longitude USALEF IHWG RLS/SSOP Yupik Eskimo North America Alaska 60N 160W
The next line (line 3) should contain the column headers for the allele data. e.g.:
Pop_name Sample_id HLA-A_1 HLA-A_2 HLA-C_1 HLA-C_2 HLA-B_1 HLA-B_2 DRA_1 DRA_2 DRB1_1 DRB1_2 DQA1_1 DQA1_2 DQB1_1 DQB1_2 DPB1_1 DPB1_2 EskiYupik AN002 3001 6801 0102 0702 0702 2705 **** **** 0101 1501 **** **** 0501 0602 **** ****
There are several critical elements to this going smoothly:
NO BLANK FIELDS. Missing data should be indicated by ****.
This applies both to the first set of fields for the population parameters, as well as the actual entry of the HLA data.
VERY IMPORTANT, a homozygote should include entries for both alleles i.e., DRB1 0407 should have 0407 entered TWICE, the other allele should NEVER be left blank, indicated by a dash, or in any way assumed.
There must be two identifier fields. These are given in the template, the first should consist of a population name or abbreviation and the second a sample id#, each of these fields should be no more than 9 characters.
The file should be saved as TEXT, TAB DELIMITED, with .txt at end of filename.
Each population should be saved in a separate file, populationx.txt.
As noted in the sample above, in the header block for each of the allele types of each locus, the field identifier should terminate with either _1 or 2 appended to the locus name, so that each column header is unique.
